description.text:
I created an Extruder Assembly Clip that replaces the screws, easy to install, easy to change filament out, and it doesn't require any serious modification to your printer.

Simply take the screws off and remove the nuts and put this in its place.

I did this on a Robo 3D R1+. You may need to change the distance between the two prongs on the clip depending on your printer. If you want to remix this and make it so you have more control over how tight the assembly gets you can add a screw to the back plate in the center and that should allow you to make it as tight or loose as you want.

The best way is remove the nuts is to totally unscrew the screw. Then take the screw and push it into the nut and up while you take the tweezers (that Robo 3D sent with the printer) from the front of the printer. Put one of the prongs into the front of the nut to hook it and then remove the screw and pull the nut out. It should forced to hook onto the prong of the tweezers.

Also if anyone can explain to me why Robo 3D went with this design that would be nice. The two screws are the crappiest design ever!

Update: 2/18/2017 - This doesn't really work all that well. I ended up going back to the screws. It will work for the first few times and then after that it won't work very well because the material will flex and it won't be able to keep the two pieces together very well. Needs to be remixed.

title: ACME thread nut trap for Mendel

description.text: I have a pre-Prusa Mendel and my crappy threaded rod leadscrews seized up, so I decided to move to ACME threaded rods. After procuring some 5/16ths rod and hex nuts, I found that even though the rod was the same diameter as my previous triangualar threaded rod, the nuts had a larger outer diameter and wouldn't fit in the existing Mendel nut traps. So, here is a redesigned nut trap with the right dimensions for a 5/16 ACME thread heavy duty nut. The original was done in Art of Illusion, which I've always found very unwieldy, and its completely non-parametric. So I did a redesign. I've been curious to try out QTmium ( https://github.com/hmeyer/qtmium ) so that's what I used to design it. Its fully parametric if you want to modify it to fit other nuts.

Only for an original Mendel, not Prusa Mendel. Print 4 of these and replace the x-vert-drive-4off.par pieces. Designed to hold a 5/16 heavy duty ACME thread hex nut, for example:
http://www1.mscdirect.com/cgi/NNSRIT2?PMAKA=03124013
Then replace your Z leadscrews with ACME threaded rod and enjoy smooth z movement.

comments.text: I was thinking about replacing my not straight z-axis rods.  How did you deal with the gear connection at the bottom of the machine?  At almost $10 each I hate to do the same nut-gear-nut-spacer-bearing-nut arrangement on both rods.
comments.author: jasay

comments.text: I used 5/16-14 rods.  I had to update my Z_STEPS_PER_MM to 4629 (with 16x microstepping).  And I did do the same setup with hex nuts on either side of the printed pulley, though the $10 link you followed was a mistake on my part.  That was for a left handed nut.  I just updated it to point to right handed acme nuts that are $3.70 a piece.  I also had to locktite them into place to keep them from slipping.

title: Coypu (Nutria) River Rat Original Skull Scan

description.text:
Don't spend hundreds of thousands of dollars buying a Coypu cast at places like SkullsUnlimited or BoneClones, when you can own YOUR VERY OWN 3D print of this precious skull! I personally slaved over a decomposed head for days cooking the meat off and buffing it to a spotless shine (I really did), JUST so you can own this beloved, environmentally friendly, warm and fuzzy rodent.

This is a scan of a real Coypu (also called a Nutria, or River Rat) skull from my personal collection, and now you can own it for the LOW, LOW PRICE of ZERO DOLLARS! (just pay additional s/h).
(kidding, you download it). (but seriously, you can send me money if you want).

Print it, use it for teaching, enlarge it and make a hat, stick a doodad in its teeth, or simply educate yourself about this giant rat. Comment me for proper attribution if used in any other manner than personal.

Please post a photo to share if you print this, and check out my other scans of skulls and bones at http://www.thingiverse.com/dricketts/designs.

Be sure to "Like" my Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/FetalReproductions to subscribe to my current prints/blogs, and see my Etsy page at http://Etsy.com/FetalReproductions for baby fetal scans, skulls, and other items to own.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

DIY Coypu Skull...
  1. convince a coypu to give up it's head.
  2. boil it for 1 hour (brain included), to remove excess grease.
  3. Place it in a tank of hungry corpse beetles for the weekend.
  4. clean off any remaining sticky pieces.
  5. Hydrogen peroxide, coating of paraloid-B, scan and share!

title: Rotary Tool Workstation
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a dremel-like workstation.
I took some parts from other proyects here, the dremel holder nut and the pinion/gear system for instance.
Then I designed an aditional rotable support which allows to hold the tool at 45 and 90 degrees.

It's built from some spare nuts and bolts, and a piece of 19mm diameter pipe, so you'll probably want to adjust some nut holders and holes in the design.
The rotable support need some improvements in order to allow an easier way to release the holder nut and rotate the body, I've made a cross pattern in it, to feel the click when you reach 45 and 90 degrees, but it's not perfect.

I'm using it with a chinese dremel clone, so I asume it's dremel compatible.
Feel free to adapt to your needs, propose some changes and share the results.

Source code

  • https://tinkercad.com/things/90GZ41TzgKL
  • https://tinkercad.com/things/kVAEjzTXiO7

comments.text:
Just starting in 3D printing and this is the first useful thing I have made. I really like it.
My base was printed at 20% infill in PLA and is just fine.
I agree with MarcusWolschon about putting the rotation after the rack & pinion so that it can be used for milling & sawing. Is anyone working on this?
In the small town where I live, 100mm M8 hex bolts were easier to find than screwed rod and very cheap. These are perfect for the gear axle, and are just cut down to provide the other bits of screwed rod.
Thanks for the design - it has shown me what can be done with my cheap printer.

author: sakshamgupta

title: LASS Field Try 1 pollution monitor case by Scott Chen

description.text:
LASS Field Try pollution monitor case, suitable for attaching to a drone or other mobile applications (like a bicycle!).

Note this is not my design, it is by Scott Chen, I just put it on Thingiverse for easy use.

The Location Aware Sensing System (LASS) is a non-profit Maker project started by Wuulong Hsu with a focus on open hardware/software/data systems for location-based sensor applications.
LASS Field Try is a device that monitors air quality: PM 2.5 and PM 10, along with temperature and humidity, and records and reports data and location via Wi-Fi.
It is based on the LinkIt ONE, co-designed by Seeed Studio and MediaTek, an all-in-one prototyping board for IoT/wearables devices that integrates GSM, GPRS, Wi-Fi, GPS, and Bluetooth into an Arduino form factor.
Additional sensors: G3 PM2.5 sensor, DHT22 temp/humidity sensor
More info:
https://lass.hackpad.com/LASS-in-English-rdISX3ccs3R

LASS 3DP case for Field Try 1, designed by Scott Chen
Documentation in PDF format here:
https://github.com/LinkItONEDevGroup/LASS/tree/master/3dp/Scott_Chen

Files originally from here:
https://github.com/LinkItONEDevGroup/LASS/tree/master/3dp/Scott_Chen/LASS_V3.1_Cover/for%203D%20printer

Another LASS Field Try case design is here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1333668
Designed by Scott Chen

So, I wanted to make it easier to level my print bed (Mendel Prusa, mounted on 4 x M3 bolts with springs), and the obvious answer was to install thumbwheels to make it easier to adjust each levelling screw quickly and easily. Sure, I could have just downloaded someone elseâ€™s design like this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13807 or this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5246 or this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13065 â€“ but whereâ€™s the fun in that? Far more satisfying to design and print your own!
So I created a design in Alibre, exported the STL, and printed a set of 4 (in a single nested print). (I have uploaded the Alibre file for anyone who wants to modify the design for other applications; sorry, no OpenSCAD files, but it shouldnâ€™t be too hard to design something similar in OpenSCAD!)
Print a set of 4 (for standard Mendel Prusa print bed); clean up if necessary, press in M3 nut, and install in your levelling screws for easier fine-tuning of the height and level of the print bed.

comments.text: These work great on a Prusa i3 DIY kit printer, replacing the wing-nuts that it came with and which were too loose and required adjustment every hundred hours or so of printing as they gradually shake loose.

comments.text: Just made this after being frustrated about bed leveling. I added an extra washer between the bottom plate and the thumbwheel to make it turn a little smoother.

title: N-Scale Model Railroad Curved Plate/Girder Bridges and Piers

description.text:
More bridges in 1:160, or N-Scale. These are a series of plate/girder bridges that are modeled in three curves (nine, twelve, and eighteen inch radiuses). Note that the source file is modeled in full scale so the exported STLs will need to be downsized for printing.

There are also some piers here. There are two styles with one being "stone" and the other meant to be concrete. The are provided in heights of 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, and 60. There is also a girder pier that is a work in progress.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100 microns, 250 micron nozzle

Notes:

250 micron nozzle is recommended as rivets will be printed. Note that the file sizes are as large as they are due to those rivets!

I may yet have to use all the bridges I saved and bash a custom version as the whole module is complex with many operating features and mini scenes. 9" radi is not used much at all in N scale anymore but Trolley line still uses as tight as 5"r with old Aurora switches.

title: 60x60x25 Blower mount for Printrbot simple metal

description.text:
Replace the original 40 mm fan with a much more powerful 60x60x25 mm blower. Combine with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:367602 for great results :-)

The blower I used is a Nidec GAMMA 27 that I found in a local surplus store. It is possible to find it on eBay as well, but I couldn't find any datasheet so I am not sure if it's really standard ... Plus, although the mount holds very well and has no play, when the printer shakes back and forth (when doing a zig-zag infill between two close walls for example) the rotor inside the blower moves around and makes "clack - clack" noises. Once again, not sure if it's inherent to the design of these blower fans, or if it is because it's a low quality one.

title: CC3D and PDB stack (36mm boards, customized for Quanum Neon 250 frame)

description.text:
Here is my version of a space saving stack for a 36mm PDB and a 36mm CC3D with angled output connectors.

The top is a remix from a nice bodykit (see source), because i like the design very much.

This version is designed to fit perfectly into a Quanum 250 frame as you can see on the photos - with the standard spacers you need a "special" USB-cable (i just bent the plug), with the higher spacer (+5mm) the port should be reachable with a standard cable.

Don't print the Assembled.stl - it just shows how the final construction should look like and yes, it is only mounted with 3 srews...

What you need:

  • 1x CC3D-Top (V1 for "screwing" from top to bottom, V2 for the other direction (photos are V2))
  • 1x CC3D-Bottom
  • 3x PDB-Spacer (high or low, what you want)
  • 1x PDB-Bottom
  • 3x M3-screw (about 25mm long) + nut

There are 2 all-in-one packages, V1 or V2 - both with the standard spacers.

P.S. Top V2 has a larger gap for the main-connector to see the two status led better.

Colido 3D

Support for the top needed, because the bridges are (for me) quite big. Infill not really relevant.

title: HTC Vive sniper rifle controller for "The Nest"

description.text:
This is a Vive controller sniper rifle specifically designed for the game "The Nest". This model matches up with the basic design for the in game sniper rifle and allows you to hold a physical weapon in your hands increasing immersion and accuracy.

It includes an attachment point at the front which will allow for additional parts to be added such as a front stock. But from playing the game it doesn't seem to need anymore added, but I will keep experimenting and update if needed.

I have included the Sketchup file so people can customize the design or add bits if they so wish.

UPDATE 26/06/2016 - 17:52

  • Have modified the tolerances so the parts fir together better.
  • Made the holes slightly larger to prevent any splitting when bolted together
  • Made some cosmetic changes and reduced the amount of plastic required to print.
  • Uploaded second version of the fore stock. Uses much less plastic now, first version was very chunky.

Printer:

XYZ Da Vinci 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm Layer Height

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Print part 4 with higher infill (40-50%) as this part is thinner and takes the weight of the controller.

Assembly

Bolt together using m4.5 x 30mm bolts. I also added some foam to the stock to make it more comfortable holding it into your shoulder.

author: Mortenf

description.text:
this is a proof of concept in the use of driving more than 2 filaments (3 here) using 2 motors. one motor drives the filament while the other drives a cam that pushes the filament into the drive shaft.
i am currently preparing to test this, but wanted to get it out there. current issues are that is does not have good access to the drive mechanism for cleaning or feeding filament and that much of it was designed to be machined instead of printed. the side plates are to big for a cupcake, but i ws able to print a few of the pieces on one. it may also not be compatible with other motors until there is a redesign, as the motors are integral to its strength.
if anyone has improvements, let me know.
EDIT: added an IGES assembly file(let me know when you find its broken, and how to fix it) and SW2005 part and assembly files. also added an exploded image
EDIT: lookes like this has been worked on a bit already by wildseyed http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10783 . not sure if i should list it as derivative.
Finally got more than 1 hot end functional at a time, so to check out the filament drive in action see http://youtu.be/CVaYHlLkvWM
and http://youtu.be/yqAGEqaoPg4 it works! all 3 filaments running:
http://youtu.be/po8KyagUsY4
http://youtu.be/-X-azhcsqdM

mill (or print) the side plates, machine the drive shaft and camshaft, print the infeed and top plates.
i am using:
2 - 32 pitch gears of 19 and 54 teeth.
4 - 5x13x3mm bearings for the drive and cam shafts.
3 - 608 bearings for idlers.
4mm teflon tubing.
3 - 4mm x 1/8 pipe push-lock fittings.

description.text:
The upgrade of a second total fail in Wanhao ingeneering.

Standard idler bolt has only one fixing point. When belt is tightened proprly the idler bolt tends to move to side and idler bearings work under heavy stress and get destroyed quickly.

This upgrade adds a missing wall in Z zxis bearing bracket and alows to mount x-axis idler properly with two mount points.

you will need:
x1 M5x45 bolt
x1 M5 nylon nut
x1 M5 ordinary nut
x4 M3x15-25
a pile of m5x1 washers
x2 5x11x4 bearings

1) Print parts
2) Dissasemble the Z axis bearing block with idler in it.
3) unscrew the linear bering and put it aside
4) Take the plate part and install it in bearing blocj with nut hole to out side and closer to belt window
5) use lines on plate to pre-mark hole position for drilling on metal bearing bracket
6) step off 5m from edge and mark dots for drilling.
7) drill 4 holes about 3-3.2mm diameter and clean edges after
8) Install M5x45 bolt from outside of bracket (leave 5mm unscrewed) and put ordinary nut on it (DO NOT TIGHTEN THE NUT). Then place idler, then place M5 washers so the would fit up to plate part.
Warning! Idler should spin freely! dont squeeze it!
9) push in nut with nylon in a plate part (might need to use a hammer lightly)
10) Install plate part and screw in 4 M3 bolts
11) Check if there is enough and not too many washers on the bolt. there must be not more then 1mm spacing on the bolt.
12) now the most tricky part - you must screw in the rest 5mm of M5x45 bolt. Use needle nose pliers to hold the ordinary nut in place and screw in the main bolt so that it would screw in a nut in a plate part.
13) now tighten the ordinary nut to metal bracket (away from idler)
Done!

Wanhao i3 v2

100%

Idler supports

comments.text:
This upgrade stiffens the X axis belt tension. No belt bouncing during jerks.
Also it saves bearings on pulley. Stock bearing die within 2-4 weeks( you will hear cracking and clicking)
it improves print quality and also durability of printer.
This is latest print from my wanhao with all my upgrades.

comments.text: I understand the issue this is trying to solve. My solution was to add a longer bolt and a jam nut (no 3d printed parts, just a nut and bolt). This vastly increased the stiffness because I could tighten the bolt against the jam nut. I'm sure this does an even better job.
comments.author: Drazen

comments.text:
Your idea doesnt solve the problem of a cheap printer frame.
1) upgrade adds a missing wall - now it is almost a complete box (much more stiffnes)
2) loner bolt doesnt change anything. If I understod correctly your idea. The solution is that bolt would fix in two places and that wouldnt let the bolt itself and the frame to bend towards extrder when tightened well. Just adds the mising bolt support.
3) letting idler to wobble from left to right is not good because first of all it can start rubbing on window frame of bracket. Tention will be different when idler will be more to left or more to right from belt "axis". Another thing that belt may jump off if idler slides to much to any side.
comments.author: Drazen

comments.text: You misunderstand. The longer bolt allows the addition of a jam nut. With a jam nut I can tighten the bolt without loading the bearing on the pulley. It also stiffens the connection between the bolt and frame.
comments.author: The_Monstro

comments.text:
Im sorry i didnt mean to sound insulting =)
I wanted to say that tightening the bolt as hell doesnt realy help because of the thin metal frame of bearing block. Metal itself tends to "flex" because it is only 1mm thick and the only hardener is the top surface.

print_settings.Notes:: All the parts have been designed so any reasonable printer can produce the parts.

description.text:
A few minor changes, to the front motor mounts.
and a re-design for the back mounts.

Also a NEW E3D - easy swap print head dolly,
and an untested 'DIAMOND HEAD' mount,

still waiting for MK8 extruders from china, so cannot test it :(

Videos:
First print, Marvin - https://youtu.be/JAmZMetpKMQ
Some SERIOUS Z-Wobble: https://youtu.be/t6d9e5BzREk

Note: Z Wobble was because the threaded rod was not correctly fitted in the coupling !

Myself and my 10 year old daughter built this printer, so she can have her own printer.
with only a couple of screwdrivers, drill, small PCB (used as a spacer - so brackets were in same height) good ruler, I did use a set square, but it relay is not needed.
and a jig-saw, to cut out top sheet.
And the panels, were cupboard doors/shelves, so no need for table saw, because accuracy is already there.

I think there is going to be a lot of Mine-craft prints in the house soon.

If you can afford a REAL E3D Hotend, then I do recommend it,
Just look at the feed jam I had !!

Also as a point of interest, a simple fix to a poor print quality, and extruder jamming, (especially well into a print - just about when you go for coffee etc.)

If you are using an ATX-PSU, then drive the hotend cooling fan from 15.3 Volts, of even 17 Volts, by using the -12 Volt rail, and either +3.3 or + 5.0 Volt rail.

This gives an amazing improvement, and only a small increase in noise, nothing compared to the steppers :)

author: MakeThingi

title: Printable vise with no threaded elements

description.text:
Needed a small bench top vise that would be reasonably strong and fully printable. Threaded elements are a pain to print. I didn't want to design where I needed any at all. So, I designed to use either rubber bands or springs. The design uses 1 set of rubber bands to hold the moving jaw to the compression assembly. 1 set of rubber bands holds the compression assembly together. Thereby, applying constant force on the moving jaw. An external offset peg is also available to allow for more force to be added and to fix the jaws open. I have validated the design in Repetier. It WILL require support material. I used a 4mm spacing to good result. Yes, there was sanding and using a file... Hope it is useful to someone.
Bill

The Klann Lego Spider is a LEGO compatible prototype of the Klann linkage (see http://www.mechanicalspider.com). Video clips of the spider are available at:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bl_5wCbvxMU and
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hz4mflE2foM Update to v1.1 at:
http://tinyurl.com/y8lhcr3 The legs for the vehicle were milled from 3/8" plastic sheet stock. All the rest of the components are from LEGO Mindstorms (see http://tinyurl.com/6nj6w), which we use to introduce first year students to robotic concepts. The project evolved somewhat during the build, as can be seen in the videos and pictures. The turning video shows a simple timed turn where the vehicle moves forward for five seconds, reverses the direction of the left legs for five seconds, then moves both sides forward again for five seconds. The forward motion video shows a skinny version of the vehicle that had to be widened when turning was added, since the skinny version simply fell over on its side instead of making a turn.

The following are notes on methodology rather than an instruction set: In order to derive the precise locations for each of the axles, I used Klann's U.S. Patent application US 6,478,314 (see http://tinyurl.com/klannpat), particularly Figure 1 and Table 1. I converted the published figures to provide approximately a 3 inch stride, which would make for a large, but not unmanageable LEGO vehicle. In this prototype, 3/8" HDPE sheet stock (see http://tinyurl.com/yzrqdct) was the preferred material, although I experimented with several plastics. You can distinguish the three ABS legs by their yellowish hue and by the distinctive burning plastic smell when milled. I attempted to use LDPE as well, but it ate an endmill immediately and was abandoned. I experimented with face milling the material to the thickness of LEGO pieces (0.308 in.) but realized that for this prototype, keeping the stock 3/8" (0.375 in.) was acceptable. LEGO axle holes are 0.180" diameter, 0.314" between horizontal centers and 0.376" between vertical centers. The material was held atop a 1" block of HDPE for milling. It was important to drill first, then mill, as at times the plastic flexed enough that the smaller parts were milled out entirely rather than being held by the 0.010" that was left in the depth cut. I learned that the hard way and the resulting foot had to be drilled on a press, which produced enough error in the linkage distances that it causes significantly more friction, which caused the foot on the back left of the vehicle to bind at the end of the turning video. I've included the Mastercam files used to mill out the legs. File ks100.mcx includes the attachment plate and ks101.mcx does not, since you only need one plate per set of feet. The corresponding .stl files are output from Mastercam, so your mileage may vary. The ks100.dxf file is a conversion of ks100.mcx and ks102.dxf displays each of the parts with its corresponding dimensions to facilitate manual scaling. In the initial stages, shown by the leg assembly pictures, I was able to use LEGO snap in pieces in each of the linkage points, but once the vehicle was assembled, due to the weight and strain on the joints, I had to replace them with LEGO axles.

title: MIKE SHELF (stackable shelf organizer with parts organizer)

description.text:
I have a lot of these clear boxes they are 4.717"x 3.64"x1.011" inches (that's not exact measure) but close. I wanted to organize my small parts for hobby and the nuts and bolts I have. I also made a divider for the nuts and bolts it makes 8 compartments. these are meant to be stacked they have holes on the bottom and pegs on top there is a lip on the front so they don't just randomly fall out and as you can see in the pictures they are very handy I will be making a lot more. the clear boxes make it great to see what you have just from looking at the front there are also opening on the sides and back so you can see in.
please let me know what you think so i might improve on it if needed.

PRINTING: I did mine at 5% infill there was some stringing on the bridging so you might want to adjust for faster print speeds on that depending on your printer, lowest resolution is ok as for me it takes an hour to print one so add as many as you can on the printbed.

author: mr_mjd

title: ToM printable x axis cap + nut trap

description.text: The x-axis caps on the ToM are a pain to adjust because the rods keep getting in the way of the hand that's trying to hold the nuts. They also can deteriorate after several disassembly/assembly cycles. These parts can help with both problems.

comments.text: The nut traps on the inside look very useful indeed! The outer part could be made using the existing wooden part with a bit of filing and sanding, I did this myself a few months ago when installing some belt tensioners to make removing the rods easier.

Another item for my old reel to reel tape recorders. A reel retainer replacement for vertical reel to reel tape recorders. The rubber retainers that came with these recorders in the 60's and 70's have mostly gone hard and do not work properly any longer.

I thought about designing this as a one piece, friction fit thing but realised sometimes longevity is best served by complexity!

Tap the holes on the Top to M3 and place a 17mm x 5.5mm or there about, spring in the slot in the lock piece (make sure the lock piece is the same way round as in the picture) and clamp the three bits together with 2 x 10mm x M3 countersunk machine screws and your done!

author: welchauc

description.text:
Functional art: Spaghetti antlers.

Here are wall-mounted (optional) spaghetti measures designed to look like antlers. The dots denote the serving portion (I figured this looked more natural than numbers).

Disclaimer: I have NO idea whether this is American or European sizing but I've followed the size that's generally available out there in the shops.

There are TWO versions of antlers. Each have a left-facing and right-facing side and a pair of wall mounts (if you want to use them). Only two small screws are needed to secure the wall mount. The antlers/ measure plates are removable, simply lift.

Why two VERSIONS? I started with the larger (v1) and then realised the dimensions exceeded my 6x6x6 print bed. Not wanting to distort the design, I created v2 that would fit a 6x6x6 print bed. Not as pretty imo but still works.

Why two SIDES? The measure plates work singly, or in a pair (if you have the space to mount both). If you use both sides, mount them so that when you swing them open like saloon doors, they support both ends of your dried spaghetti. Simply drop in, grab and boil.

Make cooking fun!

ps: I didn't have spaghetti in my larder so I used Angel Hair pasta for the video:
https://youtu.be/CVnSbMua5wI

Update 21/7/16: v2 Right Side mount and antler printed, pic uploaded

A model loggerhead turtle with moveable flippers. You could call it an "action figure", but there's a distinct absence of mutation and/or martial arts training for this little guy! All four flippers are attached by ball joints that are captured during the printing process. The front and back halves of the model snap together with the included H-clip. Some cool info about loggerheads: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=isjxWHoMz1E Just want to print it?
Then "Loggerhead_plated.STL" is the file for you! Switch off automatic supports in your slicer software. There are only two supports needed and they're included in the STL. Don't forget to snap them off with pliers after printing. Plate it yourself? Dual Extruder? Soluble supports?
Download "Loggerhead_unplated.zip" and may The Force be with you.

The model is designed to print with only two supports (included in the STL) for the rear flipper ball joints in the back half of the model. After printing the back half its supports should be removed with pointy-nosed pliers. You should see a kind of crown pattern where the support and and the ball meet. It doesn't really matter if you can't get the whole support out - the back flippers will still move, but not quite as much. The joints have a 0.5mm clearance when printed at 100% scale, which should be fine for most printers. If they feel too loose after printing then try heating the model and pressing the surrounding plastic to tighten the socket. Depending on your printer and slicer calibration the very first layer may fuse the ball and socket together in the front half of the model. If this happens then carefully cut through to the gap with a hobby knife after printing. Update: I have uploaded a version designed to minimise any first layer fusing (see Loggerhead_NoFuseJoints_plated.STL). The two halves will join together best if the surface between them is perfectly flat. For this reason I would suggest printing without a raft if possible (or sanding off any marks it leaves).

comments.text: Hello, I just had a look at the file you've uploaded and spotted a couple of little problems. Firstly, your front and back halves don't quite line up with each other! Secondly, the way you've merged the two turtles means the the large turtle overlaps into the ball joints on the small turtle, so the joints will be stuck in the backwards position that they print in, and they won't move. Also you've run a decimation / poly-reduction filter on the model, which has unfortunately collapsed part of the hole for the clip in the small turtle... but you haven't included the clip anyway, so this might not be much of a problem for you!

description.text:
Kids love to play the toy grocer's shop. Then they need a toy scale. It's a great game and a wonderful opportunity to gain experience in simple physics.
This scale is precise to a few grams other then the typical toys you get on the market. The pivot points are equipped with small ball bearing (ZZ685 5x11x5) and the arm constructed like a parallelogram keeps the 'bowls' straight.

My build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft from 6.5 mm beech plywood using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.

Tomo Kihara created a derivate of this scale for using as a tool on 'Street Debater', an alternative to begging. Read more about his project here.

I started out with a rough sketch ... refined the drawing using Solid Edge 2D ... and build a 3D model for verification of the plan. A final render helped to get a really good feeling of the proportions

description.text:
This is a bike mount for the Moto G 3rd generation (2015). It has 5 easy to print parts that are glued together.

My make resuted apparently very sturdy and the fit is too good to be true. It could certainly be improved, but I am satisfied with the overall quality of the present model. I have not found anything as nice for selling, everything else is either too big or too generic.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 Rework

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

50% and 100%

Notes:

I have used a 100% infill for the stem mount, but this was not intentional. I am sure 50% infill in this part would suffice too.

Printed in ABS.

You will have to glue things together after printing. Make sure the contact surfaces are flat and that there is a good contact area between glued parts.

This is easy to get when gluing the "ribs" in the "backbone". But if you are using 0.4mm or larger nozzle, gluing the stem mount to the backbone may require some filing.

After assembling I have placed my phone and noted the position of the holes (usb on bottom, earphone and mic on top). After removing the phone, I glued rubber in the respective places of the mount in order to get dust protection while riding.

title: Bracket for dual blower fans on C-Bot.

description.text: This bracket holds 2x50mm blower fans to the rear plate of the single bowden option of the C-Bot printer. To be used in conjunction with blower fan ducts thing 387301 to cool filament as it is extruded.

comments.text: Does this bracket have an up and down or can it go any way? I just installed it on my dbot and the fans seem to be a bit low.
comments.author: sLpFhaWK

comments.text:
No, the mounting holes are in the middle.
It did take a few iterations to get it right.
I have no issues with the fans being too low. I could probably drop the bracket 5mm or so before the elbow of the duct would hit the part being printed.
Could the D-Bot plate be different maybe?
comments.author: sLpFhaWK

comments.text: I'm using the Direct Drive option from the C-Bot reworked files, and I have it on there, turns out I had the ducts upside down.. The problem is even having them on the right way I can't use anything more than 20% of the fans because they blow right on the hot end and it drops the temp so fast lol
comments.author: ian_in_the_midlands

comments.text: Glad you solved it. I had problems with the hot end cooling too at 100%. I think mine are running at about 60% now. Angle of the fans is critical to avoid cooling the heater.

This is a modular device organizer for you developers and testers out there that have a bunch of tablets and smartphones.

There's 3 brackets: two that hold either one or two devices plus an extension bracket if you just need to add one more to your existing set up. The brackets snugly press into one another and have screw holes so the whole assembly could be attached to a sturdy surface (thin piece of wood, square aluminum tube, etc.). Alternatively you can just use them as is if you won't be moving the whole assembly around - I have mine sitting on a shelf, just snapped into each other.

The arms are spaced so that devices with cases fit fine. I have not attempted to test fit a device with an Otterbox case, so those may not fit in here. The arms are spaced about 12.50 mm apart. Brackets can safely hold a full size iPad, although I recommend you screw them down if you plan on storing multiple tablets on here as they can get unstable with top heavy devices.

Also recommend gluing on thin strips of felt so as to prevent any scratches.

Qidi Tech 1

title: Delta Control Panel Top Mount with SD card storage

description.text:
Tired of always losing my SD cards I came up with this mount. The 5 SD card slots are angled back 7 degrees so the vibration of the printer won't have them falling out.

I have a rather small 160mm bed so I did this in two pieces and they are combined using two small 1/8" dowels. I included the SKU file so you can easily combine the two Main Panel pieces if you have a larger capacity.

I didn't put a reset button in the panel but did put an access hole to reset using a paper clip. I don't hardly ever use this feature so I didn't want to go to all the trouble of making a button I could accidentally hit and create a disaster.

This is made to mount to the front face of the 20/20 rail on the top of a Delta printer. The brackets and enclosure don't go above the aluminum extrusion so if you have a spool mount or extruder sitting on top it will still fit up nicely.

Printer:

Kossel Delta 160mm bed X 190 Z

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.35 Layers X .7mm wide

Infill:

50%

Notes:

The support is a tough to get out of the small slots so I would make sure your distance to the side and top on supports is adequate. No one will see the base of the slot anyway.

title: CPAP Hose Strain Relief Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Many CPAP machines assume the machine will be at a lower elevation than your bed. If you place your machine on top of a dresser, the strain on the hose near the port can cause the cable to be damaged.

This bracket is designed to hold the hose up so there is not too much strain placed on the hose near the port.

Update: Found a bug in my design and is now fixed. Also you can control the height of the tube now.

Update 2: Improved the bolt handling so you can now specify the screw radius and the bolt height.

Nut and bolt.

This design assumes you are placing a nut inside the bracket for a bolt to lock in against the surface you are mounting it to.

The bolt diameter should be equal to three quarters of the thickness you specify (default is 2mm thickness). If you care about the surface I'd recommend getting some kind of flat wide piece that you can screw to the end of the bolt after it is through the nut.

so today ive created a gopro mount designed to mount to your print bed, or other flat surfaces you want a gopro on. title: Marble Track - Potential and Kinetic Energy Lesson

description.text: I have created a 3d printed Marble Track to demonstrate Potential and Kinetic energy and how it transfers. My name is Charlie Burgan and I am 13 years old. Last year in school we learned about this in science class. I am a hands-on learner, so this would have been helpful to me. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2HZVBdW2jp4&feature=youtu.be

Printer:

Micro 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

How I Designed This:

I used TinkerCad as my software. The fist thing that I did was make a small piece of track that I could minipulate to create the whole thing. To do that, I used a piece of small tube and some cubes to make the part. Then I decided to start the track from the bottom so that I could create supports as I went up the track. I used the small piece of track until I decided to make the first tube. I used a community created shape and I change all of its settings so that it would fit the project. Then I curved certain pieces of the tube to make it more like a marble track. I then raise the tube so that it would have enough potential energy to make it through the track. I added on final raise at the top so that you can store marbles as well as drop them. For the last step, I added supports.

description.header: Project: Marble Track - Potential and Kinetic Energy
description.text:
Project Name: Marble Track Energy

This project will teach students how potential and kinetic energy works, as well as learn what friction and air resistance is.

Overview & Backround

This project will teach students how potential and kinetic energy works as well as learn what friction and air resistance is by demonstrating it on the track.

Objectives

The students will be expected to learn how potential and kinetic energy works and transfers, as well as learn what friction and air resistance is.

Audiences:

I learned about this in 6th grade, so I would recommend it be for 6th graders.

Subjects:

This project would be used in science, but it could include math.

Skills Learned:

The students should have learned how potential energy transforms into kinetic energy. They should have also learned what energy is lost do to friction and air resistance.

Lesson/Activity:

Step 1: 3D print 1 marble track for every 4 students.

Step 2: Buy some plastic airsoft pellets(shown in pictures)

Step 3: Split your students in to groups of four. If you have too many kids, just add 1 student to each group.

Step 3.5: Give each group 1 track. Give each person in the group 1 pellet.

Step 4: Allow the groups to test out the marble track.

Step 5: Teach them where the spots with potential energy are.

Step 6: Teach them where the spots with potential energy are.

Step 7: Roll another airsoft pellet down the track so that the students can see how the potential energy and kinetic energy is used.

Step 8: Teach them about friction.

Step 9: Teach them about air resistance.

Step 10: Ask questions after each step.

Step 11: Have a pop-quiz covering what has been taught.

Duration:

With this project, it depends. If the teacher is thorough, then this should take about 2-3 hours(split up into different class periods).

Preparation:

Teachers will need to 3D print 1 marble track for every 4 students. They will also need to purchase plastic airsoft pellets.

References:

http://www.softschools.com/difference/kinetic_energy_vs_potential_energy/124/

http://www.physics4kids.com/files/motion_friction.html

Rubric & Assessment:

At the end of this project, the students should have learned how potential energy transforms into kinetic energy. They should have also learned what energy is lost do to friction and air resistance.

Grading:
The pop quiz at the end should be the only grade for this project.

Handouts & Assets:

None.
I, Blaine Burgan, allow my son, Charlie Burgan, to participate in this contest.

description.text:
1:144 (~ N-Scale) Type 61 Tank from Gundam. Based on the papercraft model (with gracious permission from rizky) here: http://myhobbycraft.blogspot.com/2009/12/efgf-m61a5-main-battle-tank-135.html

I designed it to be largely printable in WSF on Sapeways - I don't have my 3d printer yet, so please let me know if there's something I can do to give it a better chance of printing! The fence and ladder are probably going to need support, and the wheels/treads may be challenging. I've added a recess to the hull and turret for a 1/8" x 1/16" cylindrical magnet so that it can rotate while staying attached.

File List:
Type-61-test is all the parts separated but in a single file.

Type-61_Full_Assembled is all the parts together in my assembly file, combined as 1 file.

Type-61_Hull is all of the hull parts in a single file. Type-61_Turret is all of the turret parts in a single file.

Type-61_Turret_Magnet is the turret without the cannons attached. Type-61_Cannons_Reduced are the cannons separately.

The rest of the parts are what you may want to print individually if the big file doesn't work out. Assembly of these parts should be pretty straightforward - most parts line up on edges, and there's protrusions for the cannons to square to.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I don't have my printer yet, so hopefully you can help! There will probably be some parts that need support, and once I get a printer I'll update resolution and such.

With the permission of rizky, I based the design off his paper model here: http://myhobbycraft.blogspot.com/2009/12/efgf-m61a5-main-battle-tank-135.html

From there it was a lot of poly-line, extrusion, vertex pushing and swearing.

comments.text: Design works pretty well, little scale adjustment and it'll work well with the MG units. Infact mine is scaled for that at this time by using pilot figure references, so fairly large build. The individual files are difficult to print, namely the cannons and ladders. Combined assembled unit though with support it comes out fairly nice. If I can get those individual files to work for me better which is just patients, using two small magnets on the main body and head will help create a rotating articulated body. I'll have pictures if everything works well.

I guess I should of done atleast a 50% infill versus a 5% to cut time cause there was no way I could get that size to work with a hallowed out print.
comments.author: ScornMandark

comments.text: OK, uploaded a few new parts - Hull and Turret as separate assemblies.  I made 2 versions of the turret, one with and one without cannons.  I uploaded a second version of the cannons as well with a much less hollow barrel - it had been hollowed out most of the length before, which isn't really necessary.  The hull and both versions of the turret have a 1/8" x 1/16" cylindrical indent for a magnet.  I can't make it any bigger or it'll cut through the sides.  That is at 1/144 scale of course - at 1/100 scale it'll be a 4.5 mm diameter hole, which is between 5/32 and 3/16 (i.e. a 3/16 magnet will be too large).

description.text:
My Stepson (Grant) designed this sword on paper (derived from an internet image he found), so we mocked it up in Inventor and printed one out.  
It prints in two halves that are glued together (or mounted to a wall of picture frame separately)  
It came out so good, We decided to upload it here.  
Designed in Inches, so it will import very small and will need to be scaled to 25.4:1

oraltosun's eagle didn't print too well in MakerWare. About half of the eagle's triangles weren't oriented properly so you only got 50~60% of the eagle when you printed it! I repaired it in netfabb and this gets that sweet 100% eagle you crave. This model prints very well but as oraltosun mentioned its best scaled up as those wings can get very thin in smaller models.

comments.text:
Hello, test on an Anet A8, after three test impossible to print it, test on 210mm high, then 150mm high nothing to do, problem to print the tail and the left paw breaks every time.
I put support everywhere but impossible to print for my part.
Pity
comments.author: jeje63

comments.text: This print started off beautifully in the Cube 3D printer.  Then about one hour in, the legs fell over and lots of stringy filament came out.  Thankfully a friend was in the room to stop the print.I am trying it again for the HV Eagles!  I am printing it with supports this time.  Wish me luck!
comments.author: lilietc13

comments.text: I'm not sure how to print one. I have downloaded it, but the only option it gives me is to order it online. Also I need one that is 20mm tall. I dont need it to be very accurate, but do you know if you will be able to tell that it is an eagle?
comments.author: Andy7_24

comments.text: What is a good size to print this?  All I need to know is the height so I can print it to scale.
comments.author: Mann

comments.text: Well,  actually even 10cm height will appear fine. But selecting larger dimensions will give more good results. I remember some guys have used full height of an Ultimaker 2 extended printer. Good lucks.
comments.author: Mann

comments.text: My school is relatively new to this Makerbot replicator 2 that we have.  I tried printing this eagle, but it seems since the tail being lower than the body and it is unsupported the printer moves to its location and just drops strings of filament.  Is it suppose to be printed in a differnt orientation, or is the tail suppose to print onto something to support it until it reaches the body?  Since it lays lines on the same height it does not properly print the tail...  Any suggestions?
comments.author: BNES

comments.text: In my experience the eagle does require support to be enabled. Are you using Makerware? Checking the 'support' box should be all you need to do to generate something for the tail to rest on otherwise yeah it will basically start printing the tail and beak 'midair'
comments.author: BNES

comments.text: Yes that is what seemed to be happening!  I will be reprinting during my break to see how it goes.  This has got to be one of the coolest things ever.  Design looks awesome, and we are "soaring eagles" so the kids will be very excited to see it print!
comments.author: andypop

comments.text: Awesome! I would recommend an exacto knife for some of the areas when removing support esp. if its a smaller print - his wings and the juncture between the bulk of the legs and the base are very delicate.
comments.author: BNES

comments.text: Thank you for your efforts. I would like to add that it is possible to print it without support .
comments.author: oraltosun
